Posts.Title: Bone Mets--Who has them?

Posts.Content: I agree with some of the folks above - you need to get a second opinion. My husband is also a 5+4 and his scans were clear - but reality was that there was bone mets in two places in his spine. Just didn't show up on the bone scan, but did on a PET/CT scan. Surgery was not an option because of his 5+4 - he's on HT and finishing radiation in about 2 weeks. Get a second opinion ... surgery for 5+4 gleason is NOT the norm - and why put him through that if it isn't going to "help"?
Posts.Title: Newby wife

Posts.Content: I agree with some of the folks above - you need to get a second opinion. My husband is also a 5+4 and his scans were clear - but reality was that there was bone mets in two places in his spine. Just didn't show up on the bone scan, but did on a PET/CT scan. Surgery was not an option because of his 5+4 - he's on HT and finishing radiation in about 2 weeks. Get a second opinion ... surgery for 5+4 gleason is NOT the norm - and why put him through that if it isn't going to "help"?
Posts.Title: Newby wife

Posts.Content: Last week we went to the urologist and he did an exam, found nothing - then said just for giggles, do a PSA test. My husband did and it came back at 177. He went in for a bone scan Friday. The urologist said that he has advanced prostate cancer. That he didn't need to do a biopsy because his PSA was so high. The bone scan hasn't come back yet. He has no symptoms ... and is only 61 years old. Is that true ... a PSA that high actually means cancer, period?
Posts.Title: Husband PSA 177

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Replicant I would say if you have access to MD Anderson in Houston, go there. By all means. They are ranked #1 in the US by US News & World Report for cancer treatment. They're also highly rated for urology--so for a urologic cancer like prostate cancer, that's a great combination. They are one of three original comprehensive cancer centers established with federal assistance in 1971. They are one of 66 National Cancer Institute-recognized Centers of Excellence, and have conducted more clinical trials than any other cancer research organization. Get a referral to a top notch medical oncologist there, and your husband will be in excellent hands. Best wishes. Thank you. MD Anderson is considered to be in our hospitalization network. We are going to the doctor today to discuss his bone scan results and to just sit down and find out what he really is facing. Last Thursday when we were there, we didn't quite hear everything, I'm sure - total shock! I am going to ask the Urologist to refer him to MD Anderson. We live in New Orleans - but can be in Houston in just a couple hours drive, or a fairly cheap plane ride.
Posts.Title: Husband PSA 177

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by eyetat PSA testing should start at age 50 and when a doubling is noted, psa should be tested every three months. Within one year of being monitored my prostate was removed.I know that this does not help at this point and i feel bad for you and your husband .Ido hope that some one else will read this post and learn. Today much can be done to save a life with prostate cancer please tell me you are not seeing an old family doctor?. No, he is seeing a urologist. I'm thinking if the bone scan comes back bad, then get the urologist to refer him to MD Anderson CAncer in Houston. Any thoughts on that?
Posts.Title: Husband PSA 177

Posts.Content: Yes, he was given a rectal exam, and the doctor couldn't feel anything abnormal. And yes, this is his first PSA test. He has started on the hormone pills, to get the hormone shot this week. He and I are in absolute shock, he has no history of cancer in his family.
Posts.Title: Husband PSA 177

Posts.Title: Husband PSA 177

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Fairwind Wait a minute!! A high PSA reading does NOT guarantee prostate cancer!! ONLY a biopsy can do that!! ONLY a biopsy can determine the GRADE of the cancer if indeed he has cancer...I would not begin treatment for prostate cancer until it has been verified that hubby actually HAS prostate cancer.... There are men who have very high PSA readings who have had multiple biopsies but no cancer is found! I would hold off on the Lupron shot until you consult with the experts at MD Anderson and a more complete picture of your husbands condition emerges.. That is probably good advice, I just got a call from the Urologist and his bone scan came back with "no evidence of metastasizing". The Urologist said there was no reason to do a biopsy since his PSA was so high ... but you are saying that he really should get one first?

Posts.Title: Husband PSA 177

Posts.Content: My husband has been on HT now for almost a year ... and it has almost been a year since we have had sex. That is ok .. I still have him. But ... he is the one that feels terrible about it - so, castration is not going to make you feel any better. Just hang in there, get your wife to counseling or something so that she stands with you, instead of against you. That may help in the bedroom area too.
Posts.Title: castration

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by indypaul didn't have one before. might not be infection with bone/hip ache?? I'm not an expert or a doctor, but from what our onocologist and also our urologist said is that when you get "bone pain" from advanced prostate cancer, you know it. It is not an ache, it is a constant deep down pain. I really doubt if your bone/hip pain is from advanced prostate cancer.
Posts.Title: help! newbie

Posts.Content: My advice is to try not to panic ... if you read my "husband psa 177" thread - you will see that we did and what good did it do? Anyway you look at this - it is not an immediate death sentence. It took us awhile to actually come to terms with a Gleason 9 with mets in the bone, but we have and are dealing with it. Lots of folks on this forum said not to panic, we did anyway, but realize now, that was wasted time and emotions. Yours could be just an infection. Try to enjoy your weekend and realize that whatever it is, you will deal with it and you to will be "ok".
